Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Spatial Structure of Turbulent Flows in the Atmospheric Boundary Layer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project will investigate optimal spatial sampling of important variables in the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL). This layer is of considerable importance for local weather development and turbulence prediction, yet it is one of the most difficult portions of the atmosphere to sample using conventional measurement technologies. The doctoral student will use small unmanned aircraft systems (sUAS), a promising technology that has emerged to fill sampling gaps in the ABL and improve the understanding of local weather dynamics. This research will advance knowledge by identifying appropriate spatial sampling scales for temperature and relative humidity variables in the ABL using the new sUAS technology. Working closely with the meteorologist-in-charge at the National Weather Service office in Tulsa, profiles of atmospheric variables captured with the sUAS will be shared in real-time with weather scientists for inclusion in immediate forecast models. Results will also be presented to national and international audiences through peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

This research will contribute to a better understanding of small-scale turbulence in the ABL, which is of critical importance in meteorology, by analyzing the scales at which these variables are spatially similar (autocorrelated). Building on theories of small scale turbulence along with established spatial analytical methods from geography and the spatial sciences, this research will develop the spatial sampling strategies needed for efficient and effective sampling of scaler variables in the ABL and develop analytical methods for uncovering the processes impacting weather development. Specifically, this research will (1) determine the optimal sampling scales for thermodynamic variables captured with sUAS in the ABL using variogram analysis; (2) investigate the universality of parameters commonly used to identify the size and shape of turbulent structures across a variety of landscape types and atmospheric conditions; (3) share real time data and research findings with meteorologists at the NWS Tulsa office to aid in forecasting and numerical weather prediction. Sampling will be conducted in Oklahoma, a region of the country that frequently experiences severe local storms including tornadoes. The Oklahoma Mesonet is a network of 120 automated meteorological and weather stations that will be used for sensor calibration and validation purposes. The Mesonet sites are distributed across the state in a variety of climate zones and ecoregions. Data collection will be targeted during times of the year when storms are likely, such as spring, to ensure diverse meteorological conditions are captured.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Small, unmanned aircraft systems (sUAS, or ‘drones’) are increasingly being used in meteorology and atmospheric sciences to understand how weather forms to improve forecasting. The atmospheric boundary layer is an important region for weather development, but it has historically been difficult to collect data in this region due to its proximity to Earth’s surface. It is dangerous for manned aircraft to fly at such low altitudes to capture data, and weather towers do not provide broad enough spatial coverage. sUAS offer a way to capture the necessary data in this important region with fewer risks due to their small size, flexibility and maneuverability (many sUAS can take off and land vertically and do not require large spaces or runways for deployment), and ability to be flown autonomously without a human onboard. However, we currently do not have established sampling methodologies or a universal understanding of the scales associated with the atmospheric processes operating within this region to guide sampling schemes using sUAS.

This project advances the theory needed to understand the scales at which certain atmospheric processes operate as well as advancing practical applications of the data for improving weather forecasting efforts. This project developed methods for sampling thermodynamic variables (e.g., temperature) using sUAS and it contributed an understanding of the spatial scales at which turbulent phenomena form in the atmospheric boundary layer. The data captured by this project were shared with the National Weather Service in real time to aid in numerical weather prediction applications.

Contributions to our basic scientific understanding of thermodynamics and scale included: (1) determining the optimal scales (i.e., the spacing between measurements) for sampling thermodynamic variables in the atmospheric boundary layer, and (2) testing the universality of the temperature structure parameter, which is a constant that describes the intensity of the turbulence, to identify the size and shape of turbulent structures across a variety of environments, surface terrains, and atmospheric conditions. Together, the project showed that (1) statistical methods commonly used in geography (known as geostatistics) can be used to describe the vertical structure of temperature in the atmospheric boundary layer, and (2) the temperature structure parameter may not be universal - surface conditions as well as the time of day when data are collected impact estimated values.

The results from this work have been shared with national and international audiences through conference presentations and manuscripts in the fields of geography, meteorology, and atmospheric science. The statistical approaches developed for testing these theories have been published in peer-reviewed journals. The project provided training, field work and data collection opportunities, and professional development for graduate and undergraduate students in geography, geospatial technologies, unmanned aircraft, and statistics. In total, the research has resulted in one doctoral dissertation, one published journal article, one journal article currently under review, one book chapter accepted for publication, and two conference presentations.
